title: Question 133

children: A 63-year-old woman is evaluated in the hospital for heart failure. Medications include furosemide, valsartan-sacubitril, and metoprolol.
Diminished breath sounds and dullness to percussion are noted at the posterior right lung base. Chest radiograph shows a right pleural effusion.
Thoracentesis is performed, and 150 mL of serous fluid is removed.
Pleural fluid studies:
Pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)/serum LDH
Pleural fluid LDH percentage of upper limit of normal for serum LDH
Pleural fluid protein/serum protein
Gram stain
Negative
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's pleural effusion?

The Light criteria for exudative pleural fluid are a pleural fluid to serum protein ratio greater than 0.5, pleural fluid to serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) ratio greater than 0.6, or pleural fluid LDH more than two thirds the upper limit of normal for serum LDH.
The most common causes of transudates are heart failure and cirrhosis; the most common causes of exudates are infection and malignancy.
The most likely cause of this patient's pleural effusion is heart failure (
Option B

). The first step in pleural fluid analysis is to assess the appearance of the pleural fluid. The next step is to determine whether the effusion is a transudate or exudate. Transudates are due to an imbalance between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures, as occurs with heart failure and cirrhosis, the two most common causes. Exudates are due to inflammation causing increased capillary permeability, impaired drainage by lymphatics, or both. There are many causes of exudative effusions, but the most common are infection and malignancy. Differentiation is commonly made using the Light criteria. These criteria are very sensitive for exudates; however, they are less specific, and approximately 25% of transudates are misclassified as exudates. Light criteria define an exudative effusion by the presence of any one of the following findings: pleural fluid to serum protein ratio greater than 0.5, a pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) to serum LDH ratio greater than 0.6, or pleural fluid LDH more than two thirds the upper limit of normal for serum LDH. This patient's pleural fluid is consistent with a transudative process. Pleural fluid differentiation into an exudative category by at least one of the Light criteria is nearly 100% sensitive but less specific. Specificity further declines when a transudative process is treated with diuretic therapy, as may be the case in a patient in whom heart failure remains the most likely posttest diagnosis. Pleural fluid cholesterol level greater than 55 mg/dL is a less sensitive indicator of exudative effusion than the Light criteria, but it is more specific and would increase posttest probability of an exudate. A difference of less than 1.2 g/dL between serum and pleural fluid albumin levels is also more specific for an exudate than the Light criteria. For other patients in whom an exudative effusion is not clinically suspected but is suggested by the Light criteria, further testing may be necessary.
Parapneumonic pleural effusions (
Option A
) are exudative. The absence of abnormalities on Gram stain of pleural fluid from thoracentesis reduces the probability of a parapneumonic effusion.
Pleural effusions due to malignancy such as lung cancer (
Option C
) are exudative and tend to be unilateral. The effusion in this patient is most consistent with a transudate.
Pleural effusions due to pulmonary embolism (
Option D
) are usually exudative. They are generally small and unilateral.

references: Feller-Kopman D, Light R. Pleural disease. N Engl J Med. 2018;378:740-751.
